sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Hello and welcome to Euronews tonight. Let's take a look at the latest headlines.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Protesters try to storm City Hall in Almaty as Kazakhstan declares a state of emergency over escalating unrest that spread to several cities.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Amid a nationwide internet outage, the country's president vows a robust response.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: We'll have more details here in the queue.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: As tensions continue between Ukraine and Russia, the EU's foreign affairs chief vows the bloc's full support for Kiev.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: President Macron says he wants to make life increasingly difficult for unvaccinated people, as anger over his comments delays a debate in parliament over the controversial vaccine pass.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And we go to Novi Sad in Serbia to see what the city, one of this year's three European capitals of culture, has to offer. Welcome to the program. Kazakhstan's president has dismissed the government and

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: declared a state of emergency. It comes as violence demonstrations escalate across the country with protesters attempting to storm the city hall in the main city, Almaty. The country has faced days of rare demonstrations following a surge in the price of natural gas. Well, Matthew and our team in the Cube have been following the latest developments.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Indeed, Ru. Tear gas, stun grenades and government buildings being stormed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: These demonstrations in Kazakhstan are certainly unprecedented in a country where any public gathering requires the prior permission of the authorities. For days now, these latest protests have broken out after an increase in the price of liquefied natural gas.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: It's something that many people in Kazakhstan rely on as their main source of fuel.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And there are concerns that the lifting of price caps could also lead to an increase in food prices.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And public anger has now spilled out onto the streets of Kazakhstan.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Have a look at this video that was shared on Telegram by Order.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: It's an independent news organisation in Kazakhstan.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: You can see the protesters on their way to the government buildings in Almaty have overturned and set fire to a police vehicle.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Other images on social media have shown anti-government slogans being chanted and even statues to the country's influential former president being toppled. In a statement on Tuesday the Interior Ministry of Kazakhstan confirmed that at least 200 people had been detained for violating public order while more than 95 police officers had been injured. Now the country's president Kasim Jomartokiev has said that he was calling for calm earlier in the day in a Facebook video, pledging the country did not need any conflict or provocation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: However, in a later televised address, the president also said that he would act robustly against any people taking part in these demonstrations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: But information about what is happening on the ground in Kazakhstan is still very difficult to ascertain, because as you can see here, as identified by netblocks, the country is currently experiencing a nationwide internet outage. Major popular social media platforms like WhatsApp, Telegram and Signal are suffering restrictions and even the president's own personal website has also gone down. And Ruud, this makes it difficult not just for the authorities to communicate but also those people taking part in the demonstrations. It means they are less able to upload videos of the protests online but also it means they are less able to communicate on social media and express their own discontent about the political course in Kazakhstan.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Thanks Matt. The European Union's top diplomat Joseph Borrell is visiting

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Ukraine as tensions with Russia over its military build-up near the Ukrainian border remain high.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Borrell was in the country's eastern border region, where clashes between Ukrainian forces and pro-Russian separatists continue to take place.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: The visit comes less than a week before the US and NATO are due to hold talks with Russian officials.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Borre said any talks about European security must involve the EU and reiterated Brussels' support for Kiev.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: There is no security in Europe without the security of Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And it is clear that any discussion on European security must include the European Union and Ukraine. Any discussion about Ukraine must involve Ukraine. That's why we are in strong coordination with the US, NATO and other like-minded countries. And that explains, NATO and other like-minded countries. And that explains, apart from the will of expressing our support to Ukraine, my presence here today. For more on this, let's cross over to Maeve McMahon in Brussels. Maeve, Borei is calling for de-escalation and Ukrainian foreign minister is

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: echoing those calls. But what pressure can either side apply to Russia?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Good evening. Well, the European Union is, of course, a soft power.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: It can use diplomacy, like it always does on the world stage, in order to put pressure, in this case, on Vladimir Putin and on the regime in Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And that's exactly why Joseph Borre is in Ukraine today for a two-day visit, is in Luansk, because this show of unity and showing that he's sitting there side by side along with the Ukrainian foreign minister is already quite disturbing for Vladimir Putin to look. Because as you know, Ukraine wants to join the European Union. It aspires as well to join NATO, the military alliance, and that's something that Vladimir Putin does not want. And in fact, it's one of the red lines that Putin will be bringing or his officials will be bringing to those meetings taking place in Geneva with the Americans in order to discuss the situation along the border there. And of course, another tool that the European Union can use is sanctions. Take a listen now to the Ukrainian Foreign Minister speaking today, Dmitry Kaleba. We are systematically working to contain the Russian Federation, and undoubtedly one of the elements of this containment package is the preparation of new, painful sanctions for Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And for his part, the EU's Foreign affairs chief joseph borre stressed once again that if moscow did decide to invade ukraine if they did go ahead with that three-phase plan that has been reported and used those 100 000 troops that are seem to appear to be ready for war there would be dire consequences for russia that would come at a very, very high cost.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The EU is being sidelined in the upcoming talks between NATO and the US and Russian officials in the coming week.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But Brussels can't be happy about being left out in the cold.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Absolutely. Nobody likes being left out in the cold, especially officials from the building behind me, the EEAS, the European Union's Foreign Service, that officials from the building behind me, the EEAS, the European Union's foreign service that was set up in fact and established back in the Lisbon Treaty in order to give the European Union foreign policy clout on the world stage. But as we've seen from the last couple of days and the fact that Putin will hold those talks in Geneva just with the Americans snubbing the Europeans, it means that the European Union as a whole does not have any clout when it comes to foreign policy, and it remains very divided when it comes to its stance on Russia and, of course, as well on the future of its security policy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But it is, of course, worth pointing out that the phone lines between Washington DC and Brussels do remain open.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Consultations are very much ongoing about the situation in Ukraine, and a meeting will take place as well by NATO on Friday, a virtual meeting. And 21 EU members are, of course, NATO members. And tomorrow, we'll see officials from the new German government and from the French government heading to Moscow for talks hosted by Vladimir Putin in the Normandy format.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: May, thanks for that update.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Now, returning to our top story on Kazakhstan, let's head to London and join Kate Mallinson.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: She's an associate fellow at the Russia and Eurasia programme at Chatham House.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Thank you for joining us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Good evening.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Thank you for having me.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Good evening.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Is the government capable of taking back control?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And has this crisis been triggered by more than just fuel prices? Yes. I mean, we're very much reaching an inflection point today with regard to whether the government is capable of taking back control. I think tonight we will see the government trying to enforce the state of emergency that it imposed on regions within the country and just within the last half an hour on the whole country tonight, to try and restore some order to the country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The government has made some policy concessions to the protesters. But as this protest movement is about much more than the actual rise in fuel prices that were announced on the 1st of January, it's going to be very difficult for the government to address the myriad grievances that we see coming today. And those are both political and socioeconomic in nature.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: But they relate to kind of long-term structural changes within the Kazakh political economy, which will be very hard to address in the short term.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And so far, they haven't appeased the demonstrators in any shape or form.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Could this escalate to the levels we've seen in Belarus and how closely are neighboring states following the events? I think the other Central Asian states will be watching Kazakhstan very closely. But these countries, although they were all under the kind of post-Soviet yoke, they differ substantially from each other.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And what we saw in Belarus is very different to what we see in Kazakhstan.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And the main problem facing Kazakhstan today is the fact that, over the last 30 years, the Kazakh government has decimated the systemic opposition or any attempts to have a systemic opposition in the country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And so now this movement we see is very amorphous. It's very grassroots. And there is no leadership with which the Kazakh government can actually negotiate to try and quell the protests, to try and come to some agreement to stop the movements.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Russia is a longstanding ally of Kazakhstan, and Moscow has already said it's monitoring the situation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Could we see further aid coming from the Kremlin?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Aid is an interesting way to term it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Shortly before I came on air, I saw that there are reports that the Russians are spending that sending their special forces to Aktau in Western Kazakhstan. Of course, there is a lot of disinformation, and truth is the first casualty. But Russia is playing a key role in what is happening behind the scenes, particularly with the Western Russia at loggerheads at the moment. Kazakhstan is seen as one of Russia's key allies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And Putin and Nazarbayev, the first president of Kazakhstan, very much respect each other.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And as we know, Putin loathes coloured revolutions and he will not let this happen on his southern flank.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Kate Mallinson, thank you for speaking to Euronews.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: The UK has reported almost 195,000 new COVID cases in the last 24 hours. It comes as the Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced that England would not go further with restrictions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Instead, he'll stick with Plan B for a further three weeks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: That includes mask wearing, working from home and Covid passes for larger venues.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: During Prime Minister's questions, he also confirmed that he's dropping the need in England for a PCR test following a positive lateral flow test, if asymptomatic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: This government does not believe we need to shut down our country again.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Instead we are taking a balanced approach, using the protection of the boosters and the Plan B measures to reduce the spread of the virus, while acting to strengthen our NHS, protect critical national services and keep our supply chains open.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Responding to Boris Johnson, Angela Rayner, who was standing in for the Labour leader Keir Starmer, called for a frank assessment of the state of the NHS.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: The Prime Minister has said we have to ride out this Omicron wave.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: But the NHS isn't surfing. It's struggling to stay afloat.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: We've now seen several hospital trusts declare critical incidents, meaning they are unable to provide services for cancer and heart disease patients. mae ambell trws ysbytol yn ddweud bod mewnrhynniadau'n gyfranogol, yn golygu nad ydyn nhw'n gallu darparu gwasanaethau i gael cymorth i gael canolbwyntiau canolbwyntiau a chyfranogwyr.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Mae cymryd ymchwil yn dda yn y ffordd gorau i ddewis cyfyngau.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Mae'n dda bod Llywodraeth yn gofyn am ymchwil ddyddol i gael amgylchedd cyfranogol cyfranogol, ond nid yw hynny'n dechrau hyd at wythnos nesaf, ac mae ein gwasanaethau bwysig yn cael eu llwyddo ar y prysur yn y bryd hyn. infrastructure but this won't begin until next week and our essential services are buckling under the pressure right now. Well for more on this I'm now joined from London by David Chazanne. David more than a dozen NHS trusts in

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: the UK have declared being in a critical condition how under pressure has the PM been over not going further on Plan B and riding the Omicron wave?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Well, many members of the public did want tougher restrictions, but Boris Johnson's under a lot of pressure from members of his own party not to go any further. Now, last month, when he tried to introduce covid passes for large public venues, he faced a big parliamentary rebellion from members of his own Conservative Party. So his credibility has also been damaged by allegations of illegal Downing Street parties during previous lockdowns. His popularity has been collapsing. And all this makes it extremely difficult for the prime minister to introduce tougher restrictions. So he's taking a bit of a gamble on this. He's hoping that the NHS, the Britain's health service, will hold up under the pressure. It certainly is suffering with a lot of staff who are isolating or who have caught COVID. And at least 17 hospitals have already cancelled non-urgent surgeries. So, I think it's fair to say that Boris Johnson is now under pressure, perhaps as never before.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: And this is a far cry from two years ago when he won the largest Conservative parliamentary majority since Margaret Thatcher.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Now, pundits are speculating about how much longer he can last in Downing Street.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: David Chazanne, thanks for that update.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: In France, a parliamentary debate on the controversial vaccine pass has resumed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: It was delayed over anger about President Emmanuel Macron's comments on unvaccinated people.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Macron used strong language to explain how he wants to make life difficult for those not willing to get vaccinated. Opposition lawmakers said his words weren't appropriate for a president.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Some have demanded an apology. Well, for more on this, we're joined from Paris by our international correspondent, Anneliese Borges. So, Annelies, did President Macron's comments help or hinder the debate

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: and the passing of the vaccine pass?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Well, there was widespread condemnation for Emmanuel Macron's choice of words. The French president used an expression, emmerder les Français, which is very close to a word you may have heard before here in France, the word merde, which is of course a very vulgar word.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And today in Parliament, MPs went even further and described Emmanuel Macron's statement as disrespectful and hurtful and summoned France's Prime Minister to explain what the government's strategy here really is with this vaccine pass.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Is it to save lives? Is it to protect the French? Or is it to piss them off? Jean Cassex stood by the French president's remarks, saying that what is really important here is to save lives, and that is no insult to recall the difficulty that the unvaccinated represented the state and to health care personnel. He asked politicians to focus on what was really important and to resume the debate and the vote on that vaccine pass. Some five million people here in France have not received a first dose of the jab. And the French government's focus recently has been to ask everyone to go and get a jab, get a shot. The French administration has been saying that is the only weapon they have in this fight but this has sparked a debate here in this country over individual freedoms versus collective responsibility and while many believe this legislation would pass very swiftly and easily in Parliament, since Emmanuel Macron's camp still has the majority there, well, things really did not go as planned.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: France looks likely to report nearly 335,000 cases today.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: How are the hospitals coping?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Well, French hospitals are bracing for a significant rise in the number of admissions in the coming days and weeks. According to government figures, over 3,600 people are currently being treated for COVID-19 in ICUs across the country. And the problem here, Roux, is France still only has about 5,500 beds in ICU.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: That's the same number that we had in the start of the pandemic, despite government pledges to triple that capacity.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So what's been happening here is that facilities around the country have been triggering what it's called in France a white plan. That is when they cancel or postpone non-urgent interventions to give, to free up space. Add to that, and that point actually, across the Paris region, all hospitals are already adopted, have already adopted the white plan for about a month now. Add to that the fact that many hospital personnel are now absent are not showing up for work because they have themselves tested positive for COVID-19 and you have a very tense situation in the words of a doctor I just spoke to a couple of moments ago. He said that they are worried that they are very concerned and that they are bracing for things to get significantly worse during the course of the month of January.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Thanks, Annelies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Novi Sad in Serbia is one of three cities to be given the title European Capital of Culture 2022.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: It's known for its summer festival, unique history and architecture. Natasha Kovacev reports now on what's in store for culture lovers in the city this year. It entered the year of the title with an homage to famous scientists and artists, with the lights illuminating its historical heritage and new bridges. One of the slogans for the project that puts culture in the center of social and economic development.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: The program for new bridges tells the story about Europe and Novi Sad from the angle of identities, but also using current European topics, problems and challenges.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: This range of investment in the area of culture didn't occur in the previous 50 years or so in Novi Sad.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Using the potentials it has in old industrial complexes, the new European Capital of Culture turns them into gallery spaces, art studios and theatre stages, where part of the programmes will take place.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: of the programmes will take place. New address for classical music concerts will be the City Concert Hall. Together with the European title, it brought the world famous violinist Stefan Milenković to Novi Sad.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: I'm here because of my family and because it is a challenge for me to participate directly in the life of classical music in Serbia. One of the key factors is, of course, a phenomenal creative climate.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: In that climate, cultural institutions and independent artists were called to become part of what the organizers call the beginning of the transformation of Novi Sad.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: In 2022, through festivals, exhibitions, theater exhibitions theater plays concerts this city will focus on questions like migrations the future of europe female creativity the importance of peace more than 4 000 artists will be part of the european capital of culture navisad will host over a thousand and five hundred events this year hoping it will boost the number of tourists in the city again, after two years affected by the pandemic of coronavirus.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Natasha Kovacev, Euronews, Novi Sad.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: That's all from Euronews tonight, but do stay tuned for more news coming up.
